headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Roshira, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the 2010 Second Quarter Sprint Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And now I would like to turn the call over t
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Roshira, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the 2010 Second Quarter Sprint Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And now I would like to turn the call over to Yijing Brentano, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Roshira. Good morning and welcome to Sprint Nextel's Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Call. Thanks for joining us this morning. For the format of the call, Dan Hesse, our CEO, will discuss operational performance in the quarter; and then our CFO,
componenttext:
Thank you, Roshira. Good morning and welcome to Sprint Nextel's Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Call. Thanks for joining us this morning. 
For the format of the call, Dan Hesse, our CEO, will discuss operational performance in the quarter; and then our CFO, Bob Brust will cover the financial aspects of the quarter. Before we get underway, let me remind you that our release and the presentation slides that accompany this call are both available on the Investor Relations page of the Sprint website.
Slide 2 is our cautionary statements. I want to point out that in our remarks this morning, we will be discussing forward-looking information, which involves a number of risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ materially from our forward-looking statements. We provide a comprehensive list of risk factors in our SEC filings, which I encourage you to review, including our Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2009.
Turning to Slide 3. Throughout our call, we will refer to several non-GAAP metrics. Reconciliation of our non-GAAP performance and liquidity measures to the appropriate GAAP measures for the second quarter can be found on the attachments to our earnings release and also at the end of today's presentation, which are available on our website at www.sprint.com/investors.
Next I would like to cover our EPS results. Basic and diluted loss per common share for the second quarter was $0.25, compared to $0.29 in the first quarter 2010 and $0.13 in the year-ago period. Approximately $0.10 of the second quarter 2010 loss per share was due to an increase in valuation allowance on deferred tax assets, resulting from net operating loss carryforward generated during the second quarter. The impact was about $0.12 in the first quarter. Bob will discuss this further in his remarks. 
I will now turn the call over to Sprint CEO, Dan Hesse.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Yijing, and good morning and thanks for joining us so early on a summer day, especially those of you who might be on vacation. As you can see from Slide 4, Sprint had a solid second quarter. We grew total wireless subscribers by 111,000 in th
componenttext:
Thank you, Yijing, and good morning and thanks for joining us so early on a summer day, especially those of you who might be on vacation. 
As you can see from Slide 4, Sprint had a solid second quarter. We grew total wireless subscribers by 111,000 in the quarter, driven by Sprint's best postpaid churn performance ever. And we've been in the Wireless business for almost 14 years now. Our efforts to improve the customer experience by being simple to do business with are paying off. And like last quarter, we can, again, report sequential stability in revenues, adjusted OIBDA and OIBDA margin and strong free cash flow. 
As I do on each call, I will organize my comments along the lines of Sprint's three consistent overarching objectives: Improving the customer experience, strengthening the brand and generating cash flow.
Please go to Slide 5. With respect to the customer experience, I'm very pleased to report that we achieved our 10th consecutive quarter of improvement in customer care satisfaction and in first call resolution last quarter. As a result of this two and a half year, company-wide obsession with improving the customer experience, the 2010 American Customer Satisfaction Index, which some of you may know as the comprehensive University of Michigan customer satisfaction study, reported that over the past two years, Sprint has not only improved far more than any U.S. wireless carrier, but Sprint's customer satisfaction has improved more in the past two years than any U.S. company in the survey from any industry, period. 
And the ACSI is not alone. Recently, I was invited to New York to keynote the Forrester Customer Experience Forum 2010 Conference in recognition of Sprint's significant customer service improvements over the past year. In the Forrester Customer Experience Index, Sprint improved 15 points while no other U.S. wireless carrier improved more than one point. And Sprint's improvement tied for the greatest improvement achievement of any U.S. company in any industry.
Also in the quarter, Sprint received the Gartner 1 to 1 Media CRM Excellence Award as one of the five gold medal winners. Gartner's CRM excellence award honors outstanding organizations that use customer-focused strategies to improve their business performance. 
In addition, the J.D. Power Wireless business satisfaction survey recognized Sprint recently as the only carrier to see its scores improve in the small, mid-sized business category in each of the 2008, 2009 and 2010 surveys. And earlier this year, the Yankee Group recognized Sprint as the number one invoice satisfaction and number one in data satisfaction among large business customers.
Please go to Slide 6. Our internal metrics mirror these results. In the quarter, blocked calls on our network achieved an all-time best. In a well-known third-party survey, customers gave Sprint our highest rating ever in network satisfaction. Per customer care, our overall top box customer satisfaction percentage hit, yet, another all-time high in the second quarter. And our bottom box performance was also another all-time best. 
We achieved yet another all-time best in the quarter, with the fewest number of calls per customer to customer care ever. This is a win-win for us and for our customers, as they prefer not to call us, and if they don't call, we can reduce our care costs. Calls to care per customer were down 41% this June versus June 2007. And we have not been buying satisfaction by crediting the customer's bill. Customer bill credits are down 46% year-over-year. 
The improvements in Sprint's customer service levels over the past 10 quarters are truly remarkable.  And most importantly, this is borne out by our churn performance. As I said, our postpaid churn achieved a best ever result this quarter of 1.85%. And had it not been for the decommissioning of the Helio platform, which we acquired recently as part of the Virgin Mobile acquisition, any associated deactivations on that platform, which we told you were coming in the second quarter on last quarter's call, postpaid churn would have been only 1.78% this quarter. 
We're making improvements in both voluntary and involuntary churn. Involuntary churn benefits because our percentage of postpaid customers that carry a prime credit rating remains at a robust 84%. Prepaid churn is also better, both sequentially and year-over-year.
Turning to Slide 7. Our customer experience improvements are helping to strengthen our brand, which is crucial to improving subscriber performance. According to third-party brand data, Sprint was the only carrier to see a statistically significant improvement in its purchase consideration and most want to investigate metrics sequentially in the second quarter. Because the Sprint brand is strengthening, the number of Sprint-branded postpaid customers increased by a net positive 285,000 in the quarter. The number of contract customers choosing the Sprint brand is growing nicely. When I say Sprint-branded, I'm referring to customers who choose Sprint-branded services, which utilize our CDMA network. These are all retail postpaid customers on our CDMA network, with the exception of Helio subscribers and customers using the Nextel-branded power source dual mode iDEN CDMA devices. 
Even though our Sprint-branded postpaid gross adds year-over-year growth of 46% was the highest since 2001, yet perhaps also noticed that our marketing expenses have declined sequentially and year-over-year. The multi-year consistency and clarity of our messages allows our advertising spend to be more productive.
Please go to Slide 8. Our year-over-year postpaid for contract customer net add improvement of 763,000 is yet another all-time best for Sprint. For the first half of the year, this represents an improvement of better than 1.4 million as compared to the first six months of last year. By contrast, AT&T and Verizon reported their fewest new contract customer additions in the second quarter in six years. 
Going to Slide 9, the sequential improvement in postpaid net adds is our best since 2002. Even though the EVO 4G launch helped, the strength of our broad handset portfolio and our across-the-board improvements were so significant, that we would have achieved both positive total wireless net subscriber growth and Sprint brand postpaid subscriber growth without any help from EVO in the second quarter. Our improvements are foundational. 
Sprint's market share of new postpaid or contract customers, also known as share of gross adds or SOGA, based upon our best industry estimates were up for the fourth consecutive quarter and up 560 basis points year-over-year, our largest year-over-year improvement on record. Sequentially, and year-over-year, we are the only major wireless carrier improving SOGA for market share of new postpaid customers.
One way to measure the relative strength of your brand is to look at the trend in port outs to your competitors and port ins from your competitors, how you're doing among switchers, if you will. Port outs continue to get better as a percentage of our base and on an absolute basis, but even more noteworthy is the dramatic increase in customers porting in from our competitors. Postpaid port ins are up 84% year-over-year. 
The churn improvement was the most valuable contributor to our subscriber performance. The impact we're getting from our brand anchor, simplicity embodied in our Any Mobile, Anytime and our 30-day guarantee offers is providing significant voluntary and involuntary churn benefits, an excellent indicator of the impact of approved service levels is off-contract churn, where there is not a financial penalty to leave. Off-contract churn last quarter was at the lowest level since the merger five years ago. Because of our confidence in the improvements we've made to the customer experience, earlier this year, we introduced the industry's first full 30-day money-back guarantee. Since we launched this guarantee, our churn or deactivation percentage in that first 30 days is actually lower or better than it was in 2008 or in 2009 before the money-back guarantee. This is more hard evidence that the Sprint customer experience has improved.
The second quarter was a productive quarter for our prepaid brands. If you would go to Slide 10, we launched Common Cents into 700 Wal-Mart stores, relaunched Virgin Mobile and we expanded Assurance Wireless into additional states. Although we saw an expected decline in net adds sequentially due to seasonality, prepaid net add performance of 173,000 was in line with our internal plan. We did this in spite of a few short-term headwinds, including Boost inventory issues and delays in rolling out Assurance Wireless. Churn continues to perform well, and we anticipate further improvement as we look towards year end. 
Assurance Wireless was available in seven states at the end of the quarter. We had hoped to launch Florida in the middle of the second quarter, but state approval was delayed until July, due to opposition from various interested parties. I am pleased to say that we are now officially launched in Florida and Louisiana, and we expect to be in approximately 20 states by the end of the year.
We relaunched the Virgin Mobile brand with innovative Beyond Talk proposition during the second quarter. Although announced in May, we were not fully rolled out to nearly 20,000 retail locations  until the end of June. In retailers that previously sold Virgin Mobile and now sell our Beyond Talk offers, sales are up 20-plus percent post launch. 
According to first quarter data from Nielsen, pay-as-you-go customers, or what we call basic communicators, make up 62% of the no-contract market. We launched Common Cents in 700 Wal-Mart stores in June and will expand to a total of 1500 stores in August. Two weeks ago, added payLo by Virgin Mobile as our pay-as-you-go offerings, which is targeted at basic communicators and retail channels other than Wal-Mart. 
Boost Mobile was recently honored by the American Business Awards, also known as the Stevie's [Stevie Awards]. Boost Mobile's Unwronged campaign was recognized as the best technology ad and campaign and Boost Mobile won the business turnaround of the year for organizations above the 2500 employees. We continue to see good demand for Boost Unlimited, especially for CDMA devices. We have resolved inventory issues with Boost, and we were fully stocked by the third week of June. 
The results of all these actions and the launch of our multi-brand strategy position us for the remainder of the year. We continue to expect to make meaningful progress in our prepaid net add results in the second half of 2010. And we expect to see sequential improvement in the third quarter.
Sprint continues to focus on improving our environment. Sprint now has 21% of our wireless invoices being electronic versus paper. And we were awarded the Sustainability Leadership Award at the 2010 International Electronics Recycling Conference & Expo. We also launched two more green phones in the second quarter, the LG Remarq and the Samsung Restore. 
And finally, with respect to cash in the bottom line, we can report once again sequential stability and revenue and in consolidated adjusted OIBDA and OIBDA margin. Our $709 million of free cash flow this quarter puts us at $1.2 billion free cash flow for the first half of the year.
Regarding the second half of 2010, 4G will be an increasingly important element of our performance. So far, the HTC EVO 4G pictured on Slide 11 has exceeded our expectations, whether it be press or analysts reviews, sales demand or for its historic lower churn [ph] level. We wish we could get more devices and it's an issue HTC is working on. We launched eight 4G markets in the second quarter bringing us up to 51 million pops.
I get a lot of questions about Clearwire and about Sprint's network, RFP. On the topic of Clearwire, we have an advantage in the aligned ownership interests we share with the cable partners, Intel and Google. And we benefit from the many contributions they have brought to the table and we benefit from the resale of 4G services. We are supportive of Clearwire's 2010 network build plan of up to 120 million pops. And we will continue to explore with Clearwire and each of its partners' various network deployment strategies and financing options beyond 2010. As in the past, any strategic or funding decisions about Clearwire must be a collective decision among the strategic investors and the Clearwire board. Beyond that, we are not going to comment on the ongoing media speculation. 
Regarding Sprint's network, we are currently in the early stages of exploring network options with a  multimodal technology RFP. The primary objective of this RFP is to reduce operating costs, such as roaming, access, lease costs, power and maintenance. We expect the next evolution of our network will allow us to optimize our spectrum assets and will provide the opportunity for further network asset sharing with Clearwire. This also provides investment protection, by allowing us flexibility in the deployment of network technology standards. Our analysis to date looks promising. And we will share additional information when appropriate. 
So in conclusion, the strong cash flow, stable revenue and OIBDA and widespread third-party recognition for the improvements we're making in customer experience, which in turn builds stronger brands and better subscriber performance. We are feeling that the intense work on these unwavering overarching objectives for the past quarters is beginning to pay off. Because of the improving trends Sprint is seeing, we are enhancing our forecast to say that we now expect to have positive total net wireless subscriber additions during the remainder of 2010 and fewer net postpaid subscriber losses in the second half of 2010 as compared to the first half. It is our goal that the number of Sprint brand postpaid customers continues to grow, and as I said previously, we expect to see sequential improvement in prepaid net adds in the third quarter. 
I was interviewed about our turnaround recently on National Public Radio. When asked how far along we are, I likened our turnaround to a baseball game. And I said we're in the third inning. The first third of the game is to achieve stability. The middle third of the game is to achieve growth. And the final innings of the game will be to achieve best-in-class performance in all aspects of our operations. We still have a lot of hard work ahead of us. 
It is now time to turn it over to institutional investors' top telecom CFO, Bob Brust, to take you through the numbers.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan, and good morning, everyone. Moving on to Slide 12. As Dan mentioned, we had another good quarter in terms of free cash flow, generating $709 million during the second quarter. This was up from $506 million in the first quarter, primarily due
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan, and good morning, everyone. Moving on to Slide 12. As Dan mentioned, we had another good quarter in terms of free cash flow, generating $709 million during the second quarter. This was up from $506 million in the first quarter, primarily due to seasonally lower interest payments and working capital benefits. We expect to generate a meaningful level of positive free cash flow during the remainder of 2010. We ended the quarter with $4.3 billion in cash and cash equivalents, down only slightly from the previous quarter after repaying the $715 million note that came due in June of 2010. This was our only note maturity in 2010.
Looking ahead at debt maturities, we have $1.65 billion maturing in January of 2011 and $2.75 billion in 2012. We expect to pay the 2011 and 2012 maturities as scheduled without refinancing.  During the second quarter, we also entered into a new $2.1 billion unsecured revolving credit facility that will provide liquidity through 2013. The facility supports our rebanding letter of credit, which is now at $1.4 billion after the $160 million reduction we received earlier in July. We expect to end 2010 with a strong cash balance in preparation for our January 2011 maturity payment. Our goal continues to be, to maintain an average cash balance of approximately $4 billion.
Capital expenditures were $437 million in the second quarter, compared to $419 million in the first quarter and $321 million in the second quarter of last year. We continue to spend an appropriate amount on CapEx primarily in the areas of data capability, development and coverage. Over the previous three quarters, we added approximately 250 new CDMA cell sites. We still expect the full year 2010 capital spending will be up to $2 billion.
Moving on to Slide 13. We were pleased with the continued relative stabilization of revenue in the quarter. Total revenues in wireless service revenues which include retail, wholesale and affiliate revenues, both declined by less than 1% sequentially. The slight decline in revenue was primarily the result of lower postpaid revenues due to fewer postpaid subscribers and lower wireline revenues. This impact was partially offset by the increase in prepaid revenues, due to the increased space of prepaid subscribers. 
Importantly, wireless service revenue was also relatively stable year-over-year, a strong improvement compared to the 9% year-over-year decline we reported for the second quarter of 2009. This improvement was due primarily to our fourth quarter 2009 acquisitions and better subscriber results over the last four quarters, as compared to the four-quarter period ended second quarter of 2009. 
For the first half of 2010, total net operating revenues declined approximately 1.5% as compared to the first half of 2009. Whereas last year, we saw a year-over-year decline of about 11%. Consolidated adjusted OIBDA for the quarter was $1.501 billion, up $23 million sequentially and down $268 million  from a year ago. Adjusted OIBDA margins improved 40 basis points sequentially. Additionally, we saw year-over-year and sequential reductions in operating losses after interest. 
As Yijing mentioned, we increased the valuation allowance for deferred taxes related to federal and state operating loss carryforwards in the second quarter. As we indicated during our first quarter call, with our recent history of consecutive annual losses, we no longer recognize a net-tax benefit from operating losses generated during the current period. As a result, we recorded an increased valuation allowance of $302 million or $0.10 per share for the quarter. We expect that for the full year 2010, we will record a net tax expense of approximately 7% to 9% on pretax loss due primarily to taxable temporary differences associated with our spectrum.
Moving on to Slide 14. Adjusted OIBDA was stable sequentially, primarily due to SG&A cost improvements and stabilizing net operating revenue results. On the postpaid cost side, we saw sequential improvements in SG&A expenses, driven by lower marketing program and sponsorship spend, as well as lower customer care expenses. Cost of service was up slightly as compared to the first quarter, due primarily to the higher roaming costs driven by seasonality. Postpaid subsidy expense was higher sequentially, driven by higher average subsidy per handset sold. 
We continue to expect some rate pressure going forward from the ongoing growth in smartphone sales. The prepaid contribution to the Wireless segment improved sequentially, due to the increased space of Boost Monthly Unlimited and Assurance Wireless subscribers. Prepaid also benefited from lower subsidy expense in the quarter. Prepaid ARPU improved by approximately $1 sequentially, as a result of the continued popularity of Boost Unlimited. We expect prepaid ARPU to be relatively flat for the remainder of 2010 as compared to the second quarter of 2010. 
Wireline contribution to adjusted OIBDA was relatively stable sequentially, as the revenue decline was mostly offset by a decline in SG&A. Revenue was lower primarily due to lower voice volume. We continue to expect moderate pressure on wireline results for the remainder of the year. 
Overall, we are pleased to report a second consecutive quarter of improved adjusted OIBDA and adjusted OIBDA margins. However, seasonality typically drives higher third quarter costs of service expenses, including roaming, service and repair. In addition, a continued strengthening of gross adds will pressure third quarter cost.  
I will remind you that over the past two years, we have seen an average sequential decline in adjusted OIBDA of approximately 14% from the second quarter to the third quarter. While we have stabilized our revenue trends, the improvement we have seen in gross adds, along with items that I just talked about, will likely result in a sequential decline in adjusted OIBDA. 
In summary, the stabilization and eventual growth of revenue continues to be the primary focus of the company. And we are pleased that our results through the first half of the year have demonstrated progress toward that goal. Our stable second quarter adjusted OIBDA results and strong liquidity position also offer us confidence as we look ahead to the remainder of 2010. 
Now I'll turn it back over to Yijing for Q&A.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  Your first question comes from Jason Armstrong with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  Your first question comes from Jason Armstrong with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: First on churn, really good progress this quarter. It seems like, if we step back here, industry-switching activity in the quarter is on the decline, which happened despite several device refreshes across the competitive landscape. So how should we think
componenttext: First on churn, really good progress this quarter. It seems like, if we step back here, industry-switching activity in the quarter is on the decline, which happened despite several device refreshes across the competitive landscape. So how should we think about the ability to further improve the churn metrics from here. It seems like you still have, really, an opportunity. And then second on the margins, as we step back, stronger quarter on gross adds, I think that many people expected this quarter along with relatively high upgrade percentages still upgrade 9% of the base, so two metrics that would usually pressure margins, yet you still delivered on decent margin improvement. Bob, I heard your comments on seasonally higher expenses in 3Q, but it seems like the magnitude of sequential decline shouldn't be anywhere near what we've seen historically. And this might actually be a decent run rate going forward, if you can just comment on that.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Jason, this is Dan. I'll take the first item in terms of continued churn improvement. Even though we've made -- and I keep telling the team as well, we've made these dramatic improvements in terms of customer satisfaction: Care, retail, pretty much in eve
componenttext: Jason, this is Dan. I'll take the first item in terms of continued churn improvement. Even though we've made -- and I keep telling the team as well, we've made these dramatic improvements in terms of customer satisfaction: Care, retail, pretty much in every touch point. We still are not the best in class from an absolute point of view at every single touch point. So we still have improvements to make, and as you know, our two major competitors, if you take the big four, we're now three. From a churn point of view, two or better. So we have a lot of aggressive internal targets to continue to improve our churn performance. And there's also a lag, if you will with brand with respect to the improvements in customer service. So what we're hoping is over time, as more people know and understand and see third party verification after third party verification after third party verification, these are non-customers or potentially ex-customers, because that's where we really still have a lot of work to do. If you were to take a look at the strength of our brand, Sprint customers, the improvement in what we call, MWI scores, purchase consideration scores, are just up dramatically because, of course, they have experience with Sprint over the last two years. We still need a lot of good work to get that message across to people who have never been our customers or quite frankly, may have been past Sprint customers a long time ago. And so I think there's an opportunity to as they begin to understand that the Sprint of today is very different from the Sprint of a few years ago. I think that gives us even more opportunity to improve churn. So I think there's a lot of momentum, as you know, that goes with brands. And we feel as though we have a lot of it right now and we hope it continues.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And Dan, I've been thinking about medium to longer-term opportunity in churn, how should we think about the very short term, 2Q to 3Q? You've usually seen a little bit of an uptick, some of it's been tied into iPhone launches, which we had again this year
componenttext: And Dan, I've been thinking about medium to longer-term opportunity in churn, how should we think about the very short term, 2Q to 3Q? You've usually seen a little bit of an uptick, some of it's been tied into iPhone launches, which we had again this year? Any reason to think there's not going to be similar slight uptick this year?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: You're exactly right, there's definitely seasonality. We're not immune to seasonality. And also obviously, there are competitive launches, both things that when we launch, it's on the positive side. We have competitors that launch hot devices on the other
componenttext: You're exactly right, there's definitely seasonality. We're not immune to seasonality. And also obviously, there are competitive launches, both things that when we launch, it's on the positive side. We have competitors that launch hot devices on the other side, but we're not providing quarterly guidance with respect to churn. But if you, let's say forget just short term or quarter, we would hope that we see improved improving postpaid churn trends going forward like you've seen in the past. But again, we're not immune to seasonal cycles.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Hey Jason, it's Bob. On your question on margins. The last few years, the seasonality in the third quarter has to do with higher roaming with the summer travel, with cost of service and things like that. In the past two years, '08 and '09, that was couple
componenttext: Hey Jason, it's Bob. On your question on margins. The last few years, the seasonality in the third quarter has to do with higher roaming with the summer travel, with cost of service and things like that. In the past two years, '08 and '09, that was coupled with a difficult reduction in volume, 8% or 9% a quarter from the preceding year. This year, we're in a little different game. Revenue was more stable, so that won't have the same effect, but we do expect to have the same seasonality in roaming costs of service and a continuation of pressure from gross adds. So it should go down a little bit. We're not going to give any guidance as any percentages or anything. But there will be increased pressure in the third quarter.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And Bob, just to help us frame the magnitude, what's the seasonal roaming uptick last year, 2Q to 3Q?
componenttext: And Bob, just to help us frame the magnitude, what's the seasonal roaming uptick last year, 2Q to 3Q?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I can't remember that, Jason. We have to get back to you.
componenttext: I can't remember that, Jason. We have to get back to you.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Michael Rollins with Citigroup.
componenttext: Next question comes from Michael Rollins with Citigroup.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Just two things, just want a clarification. If you look at the postpaid CDMA and you normalize for the one time disconnects of Helio, does that mean that the net adds in CDMA were over 200,000? And then secondly, just taking a step back, how would you rat
componenttext: Just two things, just want a clarification. If you look at the postpaid CDMA and you normalize for the one time disconnects of Helio, does that mean that the net adds in CDMA were over 200,000? And then secondly, just taking a step back, how would you rate your ability to manage ARPU? I realized that you stopped disclosing some of the data ARPUs because of your bundles. But how do you think your bundles are doing at up-selling customers versus the risk of people pricing down over time or just simply the competitive environment putting some pressure on it?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, let me take both questions. The first is when you really think of Sprint brand net adds, that was a positive 285,000 postpaid for the quarter. And what we take out there is what -- if you take a look at the CDMA number, you have two things that are
componenttext: Mike, let me take both questions. The first is when you really think of Sprint brand net adds, that was a positive 285,000 postpaid for the quarter. And what we take out there is what -- if you take a look at the CDMA number, you have two things that are the difference. One is Helio, and the other is, it's Nextel-branded service called PowerSource, which is really a dual-mode iDEN CDMA. And we count those -- and you have to choose whether you'd count them as iDEN subs or CDMA subs, which roam in there with the CDMA subs. So the way we look at it, when we talk about how Sprint is doing, how Sprint's offers are doing, how the Sprint's brand is doing. We look at Sprint brand and that would be a positive net postpaid adds in the quarter of 285,000. The second issue is really around bundles. And net-net, if you take a look at the overall business case, the over all top line and bottom line performance, our bundles have been quite successful, particularly Any Mobile Anytime, which is what you're seeing advertised now. And you have a few puts and takes. And I think you put your finger on a few of them. On the one had, it's doing better than we expected and doing very well at acquiring new customers on the gross add side. It's really over performing very well on the churn side. And so we see the churn very, very strong, both voluntary and involuntary churn. We'll have customers who bundled plans, also which reducing calls to care very significant, which is another cost advantage to us. But with it, there is some ARPU pressure as customers do, if you will, they might have been buying a la carte, or have a larger bundle plan. They moved down to a -- we call a lower-ARPU bundled plan. So there is some ARPU dilution. So if you look -- we'd look at customer lifetime value, where the most important driver of profit or value is churn, give that a checkmark, a big plus. We have a -- ARPU is a negative. Cost reduction on calls to care is a positive. And of course, it helps on the revenue side and that we're acquiring. And it's a piece of our growth and performance improvement gross adds that we've been talking about. So net-net overall, it's exceeding our business case. It's doing very well. But you're right, it does pressure ARPU even though it does improve our overall profitability.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Just real quick on Helio, when do you think you'll be through some of those inventory issues where you'd be able to sell as many as you can? And is that a limiting factor to you today?
componenttext: Just real quick on Helio, when do you think you'll be through some of those inventory issues where you'd be able to sell as many as you can? And is that a limiting factor to you today?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're talking probably specifically about EVO?
componenttext: Yes, you're talking probably specifically about EVO?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Peter Chou has heard from me probably more often that he'd like to. And he's working the issue and HTC is working the issue. There is a global supply issue right now with respect to a lot of the components for your high-end handsets. That will affec
componenttext: Well, Peter Chou has heard from me probably more often that he'd like to. And he's working the issue and HTC is working the issue. There is a global supply issue right now with respect to a lot of the components for your high-end handsets. That will affect, I think, a number of vendors over the next few months, whether it be for chips or displays. Because what happened back in the 2008, early 2009 time frame, is a lot of capacity came off-line as the economy began to go down. And now a combination of the -- economy improving, and all of a sudden, some really increased customer demand for these high-end devices is putting some strain on the supply chain. So we're working with our suppliers very closely, HTC in particular, and try to get as much inventory as we can. We are supply constraint. So the answer to your question is yes. We could definitely sell more if we could get more.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from John Hodulik with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from John Hodulik with UBS.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: If I could ask Mike's question a different way, the seven basis points of Helio churn you guys called out, I guess, if my math is correct that, that equates to about $90,000 losses in the postpaid side meaning without the Helio, you're postpaid losses wou
componenttext: If I could ask Mike's question a different way, the seven basis points of Helio churn you guys called out, I guess, if my math is correct that, that equates to about $90,000 losses in the postpaid side meaning without the Helio, you're postpaid losses would be about $138,000? And then along with that, is that it in terms of the Helio base and sort of, do we essentially start at 1.78  heading on to the third quarter? And then over to the prepaid side, I think in the past, you talked about handsets supply issues on that side as well or at least, Dan Schulman had said that was one of the reasons for the slowdown in the second quarter? Can you talk about whether that's has been rectified?  If so, when in the quarter, and maybe a little bit of a view on how churns have been coming out of the quarter on the prepaid.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take the first half of it and then I'll turn the second half over to the other Dan. You're right, there's a seven basis points, we'll call it difference, in overall postpaid churn kind of with and without Helio. But I think that number is about 60,
componenttext: Let me take the first half of it and then I'll turn the second half over to the other Dan. You're right, there's a seven basis points, we'll call it difference, in overall postpaid churn kind of with and without Helio. But I think that number is about 60,000 in the quarter. And yes, we're done now. So there was some came off in Q1, more came off in Q2. So yes, you should not expect to continue to see Helio DX going forward. We finished that this quarter. And Dan Schulman is on the line. Dan, would you take the second half?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: John, in terms of handset supply issues, you're correct. We definitely felt the brunt of that on the Boost side in terms of the inventory coming out of the first quarter and actually through most of the second quarter. But I'm pleased to say that towards
componenttext: John, in terms of handset supply issues, you're correct. We definitely felt the brunt of that on the Boost side in terms of the inventory coming out of the first quarter and actually through most of the second quarter. But I'm pleased to say that towards the end of June, we were fully in stock with the Boost handsets. So the inventory constraint has been lifted and that was very helpful for us obviously on the Boost side. And trends in the second quarter, as you can imagine, we announced the rollout in the middle of the quarter. We were done rolling out the majority of the multi-brand strategy by the end of the second quarter and so from a gross add perspective, we had a very nice trend line coming out of the quarter with June, being by far and away, the highest gross add month for prepaid in the quarter. So good trend coming out of the quarter.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Mike McCormack with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Mike McCormack with JPMorgan.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Just thinking down about you going to 3Q from a gross add perspective. And obviously, good to see sequential increase this quarter. Can you give us some sense in our -- a month into the quarter but the impact you think from the iPhone 4 going into 3Q? And
componenttext: Just thinking down about you going to 3Q from a gross add perspective. And obviously, good to see sequential increase this quarter. Can you give us some sense in our -- a month into the quarter but the impact you think from the iPhone 4 going into 3Q? And then maybe holistically about AT&T and Verizon, and obviously identifying that at least from a postpaid perspective, they had a pretty tough quarter. Do you anticipate that they'd go after market share? Or do you think they're going to continue to really focus on margins going forward? And just lastly on your gross add number, any change on the front-end as far as credit standards go?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, let me take those -- I'll try to remember but it's probably easiest to remember the last one and move back. With respect to credit, no. As I mentioned, that we continue to maintain a very strong solid high credit rating, 84% prime in our postpaid ba
componenttext: Mike, let me take those -- I'll try to remember but it's probably easiest to remember the last one and move back. With respect to credit, no. As I mentioned, that we continue to maintain a very strong solid high credit rating, 84% prime in our postpaid base. We do, obviously, you know it's more than credit score. When you look at customers and CLV and what have you, there is what we call pretty prime and prime. So there's more science to it than being that simple. But that's really the best litmus test. So no, we have, we still are maintaining a very rigid focus on profitability. This company, as you know, got into some financial trouble years ago by being too generous. So we watch it very, very closely. But as I mentioned earlier on voluntary and involuntary, what we're finding is that our bundled plans provide both prime and sub-prime customers with so much more predictability, that we actually can improve our involuntary churn of sub-prime customers by putting them on kind of value-oriented bundled plans that then, they become profitable customers for us. So this is around profitability, not just to magic credit scores. So I think over time, we can gradually, if you will, be very selective and scientific about loosening credit, if we get them on the right plan with that kind of predictability. And it's also, of course, we've got prepaid. So we have a number in a very strong business that looks at a lot of different segments. So I think we have the right portfolio of brands, both postpaid and prepaid, to address really any kind of economic situation the customer might be in. So it's a long way of saying no to -- as gross adds, as gross add growth coming from, relaxed credit scores, the answer is no. With AT&T and Verizon, you'll have to ask them. And by the way, if they tell you, will you call me? I'd appreciate that. And last, with respect to the questions with respect to the iPhone 4, let's face it. I would not be perfectly honest with you if I didn't say everytime Apple announces a new phone, that there is not an impact in the market, that we don't all feel it. But I think what we've done the last few years is that we've mitigated the size of that impact versus previous years by having our own plan and handsets. The instinct helped us in '08, they pretty helped us in '09. The EVO will help us this year to mitigate that. But we, like all, I think the major competitors of AT&T do feel it when there's a new iPhone out there.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think on my EVO yesterday, Dan, with the exception of the battery life, I've been pretty pleased.
componenttext: I think on my EVO yesterday, Dan, with the exception of the battery life, I've been pretty pleased.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: That's good to hear, and by the way, the beauty is you can carry an extra battery with you.
componenttext: That's good to hear, and by the way, the beauty is you can carry an extra battery with you.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010

componenttext: And then second of all, with ARPU sort of flat $55 for three quarters now, no real pricing changes in quite some time, do you think that can hold from here? Or is there any way we should see dilution from this level?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We're not providing any new ARPU guidance. But we are not planning anything currently that would change postpaid ARPU from where it currently is.
componenttext: We're not providing any new ARPU guidance. But we are not planning anything currently that would change postpaid ARPU from where it currently is.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then final one, Bob, you mentioned your desire to maintain a $4 billion cash level and with the January debt generate payment, how does that influence your thinking in terms of putting more money into Clearwire? There's been a lot of commentary about
componenttext: And then final one, Bob, you mentioned your desire to maintain a $4 billion cash level and with the January debt generate payment, how does that influence your thinking in terms of putting more money into Clearwire? There's been a lot of commentary about them raising more funding from both of you guys actually over the last couple of months. And I wonder how you're thinking about that going forward and does that $4 billion level sort of preclude you from putting more money into it?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: No, it doesn't. If you do the math, we have no maturities due this year. And have no planned major expenditures for the remainder of the year other than ongoing CapEx. So we don't have a pretty good pile cash by 1231. That maturity is due in January. But
componenttext: No, it doesn't. If you do the math, we have no maturities due this year. And have no planned major expenditures for the remainder of the year other than ongoing CapEx. So we don't have a pretty good pile cash by 1231. That maturity is due in January. But as we generate cash in the first quarter, that all should work out fine. And that's the only maturity we have next year. So we have pretty and clear cash flow for 11 months next year to do any requirements we might have for Clearwire. So I'm pretty comfortable with that, and I think that will work out pretty well for the company.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Dave Barden with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Dave Barden with Bank of America.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to talk maybe a little bit more about 4G kind of results. First, with respect to the pricing of the product, we see at AT&T kind of drop the introductory pricing for their smartphones, at least for most users today. I think you guys are stil
componenttext: I just wanted to talk maybe a little bit more about 4G kind of results. First, with respect to the pricing of the product, we see at AT&T kind of drop the introductory pricing for their smartphones, at least for most users today. I think you guys are still charging a $10 premium above the run rate pricing for the 4G iPhones. I wonder if you can kind of talk about the take rates in your experience and your comfort level with how their product is stacking up in the market right now. And then second, if I could, maybe this question is for Bob, there's a lot of debate and the market right now about the comments that you guys have made historically about standing by Clearwire, ready to fund that company the way you view CapEx as an off-balance sheet item in terms of your investments in that company historically. And so people are struggling with this idea of how do we value Sprint. Do we consolidate the companies? Do we look at Sprint standalone? Do we try to merge the two together? And there's obviously a philosophical argument in the market. I would be, I think, interesting to have you guys weigh in on that with your thoughts irrespective of kind of the kerfuffle in the market about buying or selling it.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Dave, Dan here. I'll take the first part. The take rate on the -- I think what alluding is our dual-mode 4G 3G handsets, we charge a $10 premium. The take rate is fantastic, as I mentioned earlier. Your previous question, we could sell a lot more of them
componenttext: Dave, Dan here. I'll take the first part. The take rate on the -- I think what alluding is our dual-mode 4G 3G handsets, we charge a $10 premium. The take rate is fantastic, as I mentioned earlier. Your previous question, we could sell a lot more of them than we have. So it has not been an impediment. And partly, it's because if you take a look at the offer, the capability, the speed, and also for most customers, instead of $70 a month up to $80 a month for data text and unlimited mobile-to-mobile, it's still even with the $10 a good offer. So we're very pleased with the take rate. That's very strong. Bob, you want to take the second half?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: On the Clearwire question, and Dan addressed some of his thoughts at in his comments a few minutes ago. The funding that we're putting into Clearwire is kind of an offset to CapEx that we would been making here if it was on our balance sheet. But in Clear
componenttext: On the Clearwire question, and Dan addressed some of his thoughts at in his comments a few minutes ago. The funding that we're putting into Clearwire is kind of an offset to CapEx that we would been making here if it was on our balance sheet. But in Clearwire, we get some valuable partners: Intel, Google, the cable companies and stuff like that. So the valuation issue, we do not consolidate that in our operations other than equity accounting, which is around 54% now. And as that thing is in its build-out mode, it's a tough valuation issue because they're losing a fair amount of money. so that will become an easier discussion as time goes on and the various partners determine how to handle this thing in the coming years. So there's no -- that valuation should approve over time as their operations improve and we'll see how that plays out.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Brett Feldman of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Brett Feldman of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on what you're talking about, with your pricing in your 3G and 4G handsets, is it reasonable to expect that going forward, all of your new, sort of dual technology phones or iconic devices, you're going to have the $10 premium add-on?
componenttext: Just a follow-up on what you're talking about, with your pricing in your 3G and 4G handsets, is it reasonable to expect that going forward, all of your new, sort of dual technology phones or iconic devices, you're going to have the $10 premium add-on?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we haven't announced yet our pricing for additional handsets. And so I'll leave it at that. But if you listened to the answer to the last question, it seems like there is a lot of demand for them. And customers understand the value of the additional
componenttext: Well, we haven't announced yet our pricing for additional handsets. And so I'll leave it at that. But if you listened to the answer to the last question, it seems like there is a lot of demand for them. And customers understand the value of the additional $10.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just a second question here on prepaid, you've given us a lot of color about what you've done to reposition that business. Could you just kind of give us an update on what the key seasonal drivers are? When do you think that having these new plan
componenttext: And then just a second question here on prepaid, you've given us a lot of color about what you've done to reposition that business. Could you just kind of give us an update on what the key seasonal drivers are? When do you think that having these new plants on the market can get you back to a level of total prepaid adds that maybe we saw a couple of quarters ago?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Typically, second quarter for all prepaid carriers is the slowest. Usually, churn is higher, sort of the mirror reflection of what is a strong fourth quarter, typically six months whether you see the churn impact of that in OEs. Gross adds are seasonally
componenttext: Typically, second quarter for all prepaid carriers is the slowest. Usually, churn is higher, sort of the mirror reflection of what is a strong fourth quarter, typically six months whether you see the churn impact of that in OEs. Gross adds are seasonally lower in Q2. Q4 is the highest. Q1, the next highest, then Q3, then Q2. I think we tend to see improved churn. I was very pleased with churn in the second quarter. It as actually lower than the first quarter and that should continue as we look forward. Part of that is mix, part of that is just  the improved real performance as a result of the value that we have out in the marketplace. In terms of gross adds, as Dan mentioned and Bob did, we come out of the second quarter very well positioned. All of our brands are out there. As Dan mentioned, we're seeing a very strong lift as a result of the new Virgin Mobile versus what we had out in retail, anywhere between 20% to 30% lifts some retailers even higher than that. Assurance is doing extremely well and the more states we get into, the better that will continue to perform for us. As Dan mentioned, Common Cents will be doubling in size from its from its initial roll-out into Wal-Mart. And as you may have seen, we are putting in payLo by Virgin Mobile into about 40,000 retail locations that will be primarily drug convenience, Family Dollar, Kmart, that kind of thing, to go after the basic communicators outside of Wal-Mart. So in general, we should expect to see, and we believe we we'll see strong sequential improvement in net adds in the back half of the year and we should start to see that in the third quarter specifically as well.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Rick Prentiss with Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Rick Prentiss with Raymond James.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll probe a little further on churn. Obviously, pretty impressive, getting a one-handle on it. Dan, maybe you'd tell us a little bit about the momentum. Did you see it improve throughout the quarter? You mentioned that brand momentum had been building. M
componenttext: I'll probe a little further on churn. Obviously, pretty impressive, getting a one-handle on it. Dan, maybe you'd tell us a little bit about the momentum. Did you see it improve throughout the quarter? You mentioned that brand momentum had been building. Maybe add a little extra color on the porting. That was pretty impressive at 84% improvement on porting end year-over-year. And then also, what explicitly do you want to do to get to that final third of the ballgame and invest in class and churn, and maybe how you can become a temp bay [ph] raised?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're just seeing improvement across the board with respect to churn, as I mentioned earlier. And kind of the real key for us has been not only kind of the brand and service improvements. But we see differences in churn. We're actually looki
componenttext: Well, I think we're just seeing improvement across the board with respect to churn, as I mentioned earlier. And kind of the real key for us has been not only kind of the brand and service improvements. But we see differences in churn. We're actually looking at it very scientifically on our rate plan and on handsets and in devices. And we're  -- as you get more granular, you understand what rate plans -- I mentioned Any Mobile Anytime as having very low churn. The same with devices. Certain devices have very high customers satisfaction, very low churn. And as we get better and better, we're going to continue to focus on those. And as I mentioned as well, and brand is something that there is a lag in its momentum to and it builds over time and that's why things like most want to investigate and we look at other things in terms of net promoter scores and what have you are very important. And those trend lines are moving in the right direction sequentially, year-over-year, etc. You mentioned port-ins, that is where we have -- when we look at every Monday, we have a meeting and you look at port-ins versus point out, between us and every competitor and I feel very good about the way those trend lines have been moving. As you can imagine, year ago, two years ago, there were pretty ugly discussions on Monday. And they've been improving. So that is, as you know, there are fewer adds to go to go out there. New gross adds coming into the postpaid world than there has been traditionally. So you have to very much look at the porting trends between carriers. So that's a real good litmus test with respect to the strength of your brand. So where we want to go, of course is, I've told the team, I hope never see a two spot again. That's our goal. I can't commit to that and not providing guidance clearly in that regard. But I'd hope never to see that again in the postpaid world. And will -- our improvement in gross adds as well will help our churn long-term because as I mentioned earlier, even though we've made a lot of improvements in off-contract churn, very significant improvement in off-contract churn. On-contract chain is a lot lower than off-contractor and so we need to get more customers on contract and have better gross add performance than we had traditionally. So this 550 basis point improvement in share gross adds will also help over time on the churn site. So in conclusion, there's a whole lot of step we're working on. As a matter of fact, John Carney, who's the Senior Vice President of Marketing, every week, he heads up what we call a churn task force, which s comprehensive across the company. We review it as a senior team. Every week, we'd go through it. There's lots to it. We've kind of gotten -- the low hanging fruit is gone. Now it's really hard work going to them, getting the next basis point or two basis points or five basis point improvement. And we're just going to keep working to get it lower.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: If we can touch on the EVO a little bit more. Can you give us a sense of what the usage characteristics are out on that versus some of your other smartphones? And does this give you any thought about maybe looking after your data price at least on the 3G
componenttext: If we can touch on the EVO a little bit more. Can you give us a sense of what the usage characteristics are out on that versus some of your other smartphones? And does this give you any thought about maybe looking after your data price at least on the 3G network? And then I know you don't give data ARPU anymore, but can you give us a sense of sort of smartphone loadings, smartphones as a percent of your base, smartphones as a percent of new device sales? Just give us a sense on how that's tracking now with some of these new devices?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Simon. Let me take them kind of in a reverse order as well. With respect to smartphones in the last quarter, 58% of our new sales and upgrades are what we call SmartTouch, smarter touch. And that's up from 57% in Q4, and it's about 41% of our base.
componenttext: Sure, Simon. Let me take them kind of in a reverse order as well. With respect to smartphones in the last quarter, 58% of our new sales and upgrades are what we call SmartTouch, smarter touch. And that's up from 57% in Q4, and it's about 41% of our base. In terms of EVO, yes, EVO usage is higher than our, what we call our smartphone, which by the way, is almost half of our customer base now. But the EVO customers are using about 3 1/2 times more data than our other smartphone customers are. So it clearly I think justifies from our point of view that the premium, although, of course, it's less expensive from a technical point of view with our spectrum position at Clearwire and with 4G to produce gigabytes on 4G networks than with networks but we clearly can do that. With respect to tiering, right now, we have no plans to go to tiered data pricing. That doesn't mean we won't. We will continue to monitor the situation but so much of our brand -- what we're showing is customers will pay a premium for simplicity and where our bundled plans and our simple plans are helping us in churn, are helping our brand, so we won't take the decision lightly to move away from our current structure to something as you're discussing around tiering. So I'm not excluding it as a future possibility  but we currently have no plans to do that and we see no need currently to move in that direction.
