headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Kerry and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the third quarter earnings conference call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. Thank you.I
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Kerry and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the third quarter earnings conference call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. Thank you.
Id now like to turn the call over to your Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Yijing Brentano. Please go ahead.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kerry. Good morning and welcome to Sprint Nextels third quarter 2010 earnings call. Thanks for joining us this morning. For the format of the call, Dan Hesse, our CEO will discuss operational performance in the quarter, and then our CFO, Bob
componenttext:
Thank you, Kerry. Good morning and welcome to Sprint Nextels third quarter 2010 earnings call. Thanks for joining us this morning. For the format of the call, Dan Hesse, our CEO will discuss operational performance in the quarter, and then our CFO, Bob Brust will cover the financial aspects of the quarter.
Before we get underway, let me remind you that our release and the presentation slides that accompany this call are both available on the Investor Relations page of the Sprint Web site.
Slide two is our cautionary statement. I want to point out that in our remarks this morning we will be discussing forward-looking information, which involves a number of risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ materially from our forward-looking statements.
We provide a comprehensive list of the risk factors in our SEC filings, which I encourage you to review, including our Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2009, and in Part II Item 1A risk factors of our quarterly reports on Form 10-Q.
Turning to slide three, throughout our call, we will refer to several non-GAAP metrics. Reconciliations of our non-GAAP performance and liquidity measures to the appropriate GAAP measures for the third quarter can be found on the attachments to our earnings release and also at the end of todays presentation, which are available on our Web site at www.sprint.com/investors.
Next, I would like to cover our EPS results. Basic and diluted loss per common share for the third quarter was $0.30 compared to $0.25 in the second quarter 2010 and $0.17 in the year ago period. The sequential change in EPS was due primarily to drivers that also impacted the sequential change in OIBDA, which Bob Brust will discuss in more detail later on the call.
I will now turn the call over to Sprints CEO, Dan Hesse.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Yijing, and thank you to everyone on the call for joining us this morning.If youd turn to slide four, I was asked at an investor conference recently to describe Sprints performance in one word, and I chose the word Momentum. Our l
componenttext:
Thank you, Yijing, and thank you to everyone on the call for joining us this morning.
If youd turn to slide four, I was asked at an investor conference recently to describe Sprints performance in one word, and I chose the word Momentum. Our last two quarters, the second and third quarters of 2010 represent the best quarters ever for Sprint, both in postpaid churn and in year-over-year improvement in postpaid net adds, driven by our best retail net add performance in over four years.
We grew total wireless subscribers by 644,000 in the third quarter, our highest quarterly net add total since 2006.
As is my habit, Ill discuss our results in the context of Sprints three overarching priorities
The customer experience, the brand, and cash. But with a change of pace, let me start with the third, cash, primarily driven by more postpaid and prepaid gross adds and upgrades plus some anticipated seasonal factors, quarterly OIBDA was driven down sequentially to $1.34 billion.
Year-to-date free cash flow now stands at $1.6 billion, allowing us to maintain strong liquidity with cash and cash equivalents balance of $4.7 billion. Total net operating revenues increased sequentially and year-over-year.
Please go to slide #five, with respect to the customer experience, I am pleased to report that weve achieved our 11th consecutive quarter of improvement in customer care satisfaction and in first call resolution. Top-box satisfaction and bottom-box satisfaction both achieved all time bests, as did first call resolution.
Our networks achieved yet another all-time best result for fewest blocked calls. In a recent third-party survey, our customers gave Sprint our highest rating ever on network satisfaction.
According to the recent J.D. Power and Associates Wireless Call Quality Performance Study, Sprint came in first or second place in five of six regions, and we have shown the most improvement of any carrier over a three-year period.
In the J.D. Power Retail Sales Satisfaction Study, Sprint moved from last place in recent years to a virtual tie for first place. In the Vocalabs National Customer Service Survey, Sprints call satisfaction tied for first place.
On the business side, we won seven ATLANTIC-ACM Awards for Business Connectivity and Wireless Business Excellence, and Sprint again walked away with the top honors in the Nemertes 2010 PilotHouse Awards for MPLS Services, receiving the top overall score.
The customer experience improvements are reflected in our churn results. As mentioned, the last two quarters have been the best two churn quarters in our history. The percentage of postpaid customers that carry a prime credit rating remains at a strong 84%, an important determinant of involuntary churn.
On the voluntary side, customers who are on contract churn at a lower rate than those who are off contract. We are getting more customers on contract, but our off contract churn the past two quarters has been our lowest on record, and our return rate in the first 30 days is actually lower since we launched Sprints unique full 30-day money back guarantee this year than it has been for any previous year on record.
Moving to slide #six, in the brand, the Sprint brand continues to gain strength. One measure of brand health is subscribers. In the third quarter, we had positive postpaid net adds for the Sprint brand for the fourth consecutive quarter.
In the second quarter, the Sprint brand was the fastest growing postpaid brand of all major postpaid brands in terms of net new customers. 354,000 net adds in the third quarter represents over a 5% annualized growth rate in the size of the total Sprint postpaid customer base. So, it is likely the brand will achieve this fastest growing distinction yet again this quarter.
Virtually all of Sprints brand metrics have improved year-over-year. As I have mentioned on previous calls, Sprint brand metrics like most want to investigate and purchase consideration have improved much more quickly amongst Sprint customers, who have experience our improved customer service than they have with non-customers.
It is in this context that I am pleased to announce that we are net port positive for both the Sprint brand and on the CDMA platform for the first time on record, that is based on our porting data, more customers are switching to Sprint than are switching from Sprint. An indication of how the brand is strengthened with non-customers is that port-ins from our competitors have practically doubled year-over-year. Based upon Sprints data, they are up 95%.
Our share of postpaid gross adds improved for the fifth consecutive quarter, and we estimate its up over 400 basis points year-over-year. Year-over-year total postpaid net add performance improved by almost 700,000, our best third quarter year-over-year improvement ever. As I mentioned earlier, our 644,000 total company net adds in the quarter is our best since 2006.
Please turn to slide seven; devices are becoming increasingly important in attracting and retaining customers. PCWorld ranks Samsung Epic 4G launched in the third quarter and HTC EVO 4Gs launched in the second as the two best smartphones on the market, ahead of the iPhone 4 and ahead of every other Android device.
ZDNet ranks the EVO as the best smartphone on the market. Each device has a long list of accolades and smartphones are helping to fuel our momentum with 60% of our Sprint handset sales and upgrades being smartphones in the quarter.
Also in the third quarter, Sprint launched the Samsung Intercept, Sanyos Innuendo and Vero, the Blackberry 9330 Curve, the Motorola i1 which is the worlds first Nextel direct connect smartphone powered by Android, and the Franklin Wireless U600, which is 3G/4G USB modem.
In prepaid, we launched Motorolas RAMBLER and BALI, Samsung Seek and Intercept, and the Blackberry 8530.
If you turn to slide #eight, in prepaid our multi-brand strategy allows us to address multiple segments with specific offers, distinct brand identities, and unique business models. Despite the extremely competitive environment and the recent integration of prepaid into Sprints consumer organization, we feel we have momentum.
Prepaid net adds of 471,000 are an improvement of almost 300,000 from last quarter with churn improving 29 basis points from Q2 to our lowest prepaid churn level in almost five years.
We continued to enhance the Boost CDMA device lineup with the Blackberry Curve and our first touch screen QWERTY, the Samsung Seek. Two weeks ago we launched the next evolution of Boost, Monthly Unlimited with Shrinkage.
This revolutionary approach rewards customers for on time payments by shrinking their monthly bills after six, 12 and 18 on time payments. This is a win-win for Boost and its customers.
Lastly, two important brand metrics for Boost, brand awareness and purchase consideration, both reached all time highs in our most recent study.
Assurance Wireless was available in 11 states at the end of the quarter, and as we said last quarter, we plan on being in 20 states by the end of the year.
We are re-launching the Virgin Mobile brand. Virgin Mobile launched its Crazy Life national marketing campaign in July. Virgin Mobiles Beyond Talk launched its first Android device, the Samsung Intercept in October giving it compelling Blackberry and Android offers. We expect to see a growth in prepaid net adds in the fourth quarter.
Spring continues to innovate and lead in the areas of open and simplicity, and weve added another proof point of this recently with our announcement of Sprint ID which is on slide nine. Sprint ID is about accessing content. There are so many apps out there. Google, I think just yesterday reported that Android has over 100,000, that mobile users need a trusted app search and aggregation partner to simplify navigating through this ocean of apps and finding the best and most relevant apps for their needs.
To launch this revolutionary concept, weve lined up some of the worlds best brands like Yahoo!, HSN, Disney, ESPN, LatCel and eBay. Sprint ID opens a two-way street between content providers and users, and Sprints open philosophy enables this rather than restricts it.
ID lets customers download packs of apps, widgets, ring tones and wallpapers aggregated and optimized by a trusted brand. A customer can have up to five IDs at once be they personal or business.
We announced three new Sprint ID-enabled Android devices, the Samsung Transform, the Sanyo Zio and the LG Optimus S priced at under $150, $100, and under $50 respectively. Many content providers will also be new distribution partners for us. Improving our environment continues to be a top Sprint priority.
If you go to slide #10, youll see that Newsweek ranks Sprint number 6 nationally among the 100 greenest companies, the only telecom company in the top 50, as a matter of fact, the only one in the top 95.
Sprint also placed first among all technology companies for actual environmental impact, which measures 750 performance metrics. Out of the 500 companies researched only one scored higher in this measure.
We recently launched a certified pre-owned device program to give wireless phones a second life. This program not only allows customers to get one of todays devices at a great value, but it allows helps Sprint to achieve our aggressive reuse and recycling goals.
All Sprint certified pre-owned devices are thoroughly inspected, tested, and if necessary remanufactured according to original equipment manufacturer new unit specifications and they come with a 30 day return policy. Devices available include BlackBerry Tour, Samsung Reclaim in green, and the Sanyo 2700 in pink and blue.
PC Magazine awarded the Samsung Restore and the LG Remarq its GreenTech seal, joining the Samsung Reclaim, which was also named worlds greenest cell phone by CallFinder.
Many on this call are investors, so you may be interested to know that in August, Sprint was chosen one of the 20 most responsible companies in the U.S. by Governance Metrics International out of 4,100 companies evaluated.
The overall ratings are based on six broad categories, Board accountability, financial disclosure and internal controls, shareholder rights, remuneration, market for control and corporate behavior.
Leading in 4G has been an important element of our strategy this year. In the third quarter, we launched in 19 4G markets including Jacksonville, Boston, Providence, Orlando, Minneapolis, Saint Paul and Pittsburg, and fourth quarter markets planned includes, New York, L.A. and San Francisco.
For sometime, Sprint has been in discussions with Clearwire regarding the financial status of its ongoing operations as well as Sprint potentially providing new financing. We expect those discussions to continue as we review alternatives with Clearwire. There is no assurance that the discussions will result in any transaction with Clearwire, and we will provide no additional comments on this matter.
Also, as I mentioned on last quarters earnings call, we intend, through the network modernization plan to enhance service quality and coverage, create network flexibility, reduce operating costs and improve environmental sustainability.
The plan focuses on upgrading the existing EVDO network and providing technology flexibility for 4G. Results of trial activities have shown positive gains in coverage and performance, in line with expectations.
We expect that improved coverage and next-generation backhaul solutions will enable Sprint to reduce roaming and access costs.
The deployment of multimode equipment allows Sprint to more feasibly consider new technologies using available spectrum bands and reduce future deployment costs.
Under the network plan, if we chose, we can reallocate a portion of available iDEN 800 MHz 800 spectrum to provision CDMA services, giving customers the benefit of enhanced in-building coverage associated with the 800 MHz band.
The implementation of the network modernization plan should further Sprints reputation as a leader in environmental responsibility through improvements in physical footprint, power consumption and cooling requirements. We will provide more details on the overall plan when vendor selection is complete later this year.
So in conclusion, although our momentum continues as we have achieved a number of all-time bests for two quarters in a row, we realize we have much progress still to make. We are in a hyper competitive industry with strong, capable competitors, so making continued progress is hard work, but we intend to persevere.
I will now turn it over to our Chief Financial Officer, Bob Brust who will discuss our financial performance.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan, and good morning to everyone. Moving on to slide #11, we are pleased with the continued stabilization of revenue on both a sequential and year-over-year basis. Total quarterly revenues grew year-over-year for the first time in more than three
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan, and good morning to everyone. Moving on to slide #11, we are pleased with the continued stabilization of revenue on both a sequential and year-over-year basis. Total quarterly revenues grew year-over-year for the first time in more than three years. This improvement was the result of acquisitions during the fourth quarter of 2009, and higher equipment and prepaid service revenues, partially offset by lower wireline and postpaid service revenues.
Total quarterly revenues improved sequentially primarily due to higher equipment revenue. Wireless service revenues which include retail, wholesale, and affiliate revenues were also relatively stable sequentially and year-over-year. The reduction in postpaid subscriber losses and the continued growth in prepaid subscribers have been the key drivers in stabilizing revenue.
In the third quarter of 2009, Sprint lost 545,000 wireless subscribers, and this year in the third quarter, we gained 644,000 total wireless subscribers. This year-over-year improvement of almost $1.2 million net subscriber additions has had a meaningful impact on our revenue results. Revenue improvement continues to be a primary focus for the company.
Consolidated adjusted OIBDA for the quarter was $1.339 billion, down $162 million sequentially and down $167 million from a year ago. Adjusted OIBDA margins declined 200 basis points sequentially.
Adjusted OIBDA declined sequentially primarily due to higher retail gross adds and upgrades which drove higher subsidy and selling expenses. Both postpaid and prepaid gross adds increased by more than 10% as compared to the second quarter. Although we incurred cost to bring new customers on to our network, it is money well spent.
As we have said, an important factor in turning around the companys financial performance is growing our customer base, and as a result, improving revenue.
Looking ahead to the fourth quarter, we expect that postpaid gross adds will improve sequentially, driving higher associated subsidy and selling expense. Cost of service was higher sequentially due largely to the effects of seasonality, including higher roaming, service and repair and cell site utility expenses.
Postpaid ARPU remains stable sequentially at $55. The mix of subscribers in our postpaid customer base who own a smartphone continues to grow, which along with Any Mobile, Anytime helped drive adoption of data base bundled plans.
However, the positive impact of higher monthly recurring charges was offset by lower usage based charges including overage. Prepaid ARPU was essentially flat. Looking forward, overall prepaid ARPU will be impacted in the short term by shifts in mix of our prepaid subscriber base along with our brands.
Wireline contribution to adjusted OIBDA was relatively stable sequentially as the revenue decline was mostly offset by a decline in cost of service. Revenue was lower primarily due to lower voice volume and adjustments associated with carrier disputes impacting IP.
The improvement in cost of service was primarily driven by lower voice volume and a slight improvement in switched access rates. We expect pressure on wireline revenue and OIBDA on the fourth quarter driven primarily by continued lower voice volume.
Moving to slide 13, we generated $384 million of free cash flow in the third quarter. This was down from $709 million in the second quarter primarily due to a reduction in cash flow from operations, which includes higher interest payments which is typical for the third quarter. Through the first three quarters of 2010, we have generated a net total of $1.6 billion free cash flow.
We expect to continue to generate a meaningful level of positive cash flow in the fourth quarter. We ended the quarter with $4.7 billion in cash and cash equivalents. As we discussed during our second quarter earnings call, we have repaid the $750 million note that came due on June of 2010. This was our only note maturity due in 2010.
Looking ahead at debt maturities, we have $1.65 billion maturing in January of 2011 and $2.75 billion in 2012. We expect to pay the 2011 and 2012 maturities as scheduled.
We expect to end 2010 with a strong cash balance in preparation for our first quarter 2011 maturity payment. Our goal continues to be to maintain an average cash balance of approximately $4 billion.
Capital expenditures were $462 million in the third quarter compared to $437 million in the second quarter and $431 million in the third quarter of 2009. Capital investment in 2010 has focused on wireless quality, coverage and capacity to maintain competitive positions in data services and network quality.
Our total cell sites including CDMA and iDEN is approximately 68,000 reflecting the additions from the iPCS acquisition. We still expect that full year 2010 capital spending will be up to $2 billion.
In summary, our priorities have remained constant. In 2010, our focus is on stabilizing revenue. Next year if our subscriber results continue to improve, we expect to start seeing revenue growth.
We have made progress on our key objectives through the first three quarters of 2010. We still have a lot more work to do on the turnaround, but we are encouraged by how far we have come.
Now, I will turn it back to Yijing for questions.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. In just a minute, Kerry will instruct our listeners on how to queue up for the question-and-answer session. I want to point out that you may access an audio replay or webcast of our presentation on www.sprint.com/investors.We will now open
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. In just a minute, Kerry will instruct our listeners on how to queue up for the question-and-answer session. I want to point out that you may access an audio replay or webcast of our presentation on www.sprint.com/investors.
We will now open the lines for your questions. Kerry, please instruct our participants.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: (Operator instructions) Your first question will come from John Hodulik.
componenttext: (Operator instructions) Your first question will come from John Hodulik.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, good morning. Dan, could you talk a little bit about the trends in the iDEN business? It looks like the adds there fell off a bit after some stability here in the third quarter, so some commentary on whats happening on that side?And the
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, good morning. Dan, could you talk a little bit about the trends in the iDEN business? It looks like the adds there fell off a bit after some stability here in the third quarter, so some commentary on whats happening on that side?
And then as we look forward, obviously there is a lot of speculation about AT&T losing exclusivity on the iPhone, can you give us a sense of how you think the market changes if that happens and would you foresee maybe pressure on gross add share or higher churn if in fact in the first quarter say Verizon which is the real speculation gets the iPhone?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. First, youre right. Subs are declining on the iDEN network, and as I mentioned earlier on the call, we are doing, I think a lot for our customers on iDEN. They are being provided with the best call quality, lowest blocking rates that they
componenttext:
Thanks, John. First, youre right. Subs are declining on the iDEN network, and as I mentioned earlier on the call, we are doing, I think a lot for our customers on iDEN. They are being provided with the best call quality, lowest blocking rates that theyve ever had. We continue to launch new devices. Im talking on the postpaid side. On the prepaid side, what youre seeing is with the launch of Boost unlimited on CDMA with some attractive and more attractively priced CDMA devices an increasing number of prepaid customers, theyre looking at Boost are choosing CDMA over iDEN.
So were really focusing on iDEN on keeping churn down and actually churn is beginning to approach CDMA levels of churn on postpaid, so were doing a better job on churn on iDEN. What were not doing though is we have limited advertising and marketing dollars, were spending very little on iDEN going after new customers, because if you think if your marketing spend is a zero sum gain, were going to get a better return on that investment putting that on the Sprint brand than on the Nextel brand.
So you are seeing if you will a decline in both postpaid and prepaid customers on the iDEN network, but were focusing on providing them with great service and what its allowing us to do is, if you will, going to form or use some of that 800 MHz spectrum, which we are trialing and testing now, potentially on CDMA to provide better in-building and service quality on our CDMA service, so this is very valuable spectrum that we can get good utilization out of.
And as I mentioned also from a device point of view, we launched the first Android handset on iDEN in the third quarter. Secondly, with respect to the iPhone, its hard to speculate on that. Well just have to see what happens, but quite frankly of course, all the carriers are thinking about 2011 and the implications, but I just dont want to speculate on it.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks.
componenttext: Okay, thanks.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from Michael Rollins.
componenttext: Your next question will come from Michael Rollins.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, good morning. Dan, you talked a bit about the improvement in reporting ratios and the share of gross adds. Can you talk a little bit more of how you would weight that between devices versus rate plans thats driving that?And then can you give us a
componenttext:
Hi, good morning. Dan, you talked a bit about the improvement in reporting ratios and the share of gross adds. Can you talk a little bit more of how you would weight that between devices versus rate plans thats driving that?
And then can you give us a sense, I know you talked about smartphones as a percent of upgrades or handset sales, but can you give us a sense of what the totality of the penetration is in the base and how you see that moving over the next 12 months?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, Michael. Let me take them kind of backwards. I think your second question was with respect to smartphones in the base, so 60% of our new sales, if you will, of phones both gross adds and upgrades, 60% was smartphones this quarter which brings us to a
componenttext:
Hey, Michael. Let me take them kind of backwards. I think your second question was with respect to smartphones in the base, so 60% of our new sales, if you will, of phones both gross adds and upgrades, 60% was smartphones this quarter which brings us to about 45% of our base being smartphones, if that answers your question.
The second question had to do with, I think what is driving our improvements in SoGA and port ratios and what have you between rate plans and devices. Id say its really both of them. Weve improved our device line up very significantly, and one of the very key trends in our industry has been, each year, that devices are becoming a more and more important part of the marketing plan and what customers base their decisions on.
As a matter of fact, its probably becoming the most important overall factor, and it was not that case just a couple of years ago. But clearly the rate plans are important, and very importantly, from a port out point of view because if customers are on a good rate plan and they like the nature of the rate plan, the simplicity of the rate plan, the value of it, they are much less likely to leave.
So, our focus is on devices, the network, the quality of the network, both 3G and 4G, first 4G is important, an improved customer experience because as you also heard on the call was that our brand metrics continue to improve, but theyre up sharply among our existing customers, so thats helping with churn. So net-net, for us, we believe they are both important devices and rate plans, but as time goes on, devices are becoming even more important than rate plans.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks.
componenttext: Thanks.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from David Barden.
componenttext: Your next question will come from David Barden.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, guys. Thanks for taking the question. Two, if I could please. Bob, maybe the first question is on ARPU. Could you dig in a little bit further into this loss of overage that seems to be impacting ARPU? I guess as I look at it, year-over-year you
componenttext:
Thanks, guys. Thanks for taking the question. Two, if I could please. Bob, maybe the first question is on ARPU. Could you dig in a little bit further into this loss of overage that seems to be impacting ARPU? I guess as I look at it, year-over-year youve lost say, 1 million lower ARPU iDEN customers. Youve added higher ARPU CDMA customers, the vast majority of upgrades in gross ads are smartphones which are higher ARPU relative to the base. So it seems strange that we havent been able to see more of that come through. And Im wondering if its because older customers are repricing at lower plans. If you could dig into that a little bit more itd be great.
And then second, maybe Dan, not necessarily on the Clearwire question directly, but Clearwire has been throwing out a lot of options to show people that there are many strategies that they have. I think the sense is that Sprint has only one strategy right now which is, Clearwire, which may or may not be true. What is Sprints backup plan if Clearwires build just stops in the first part of 2011 and you dont have a broad 4G strategy for 2011 and 2012?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: David, on the ARPU, there is several things working in there. The rate is stabilizing with the 4G contribution and the extra charge we put on that. We have a shift toward more bundled rate plans going on, and our overages have been declining. So, all of t
componenttext: David, on the ARPU, there is several things working in there. The rate is stabilizing with the 4G contribution and the extra charge we put on that. We have a shift toward more bundled rate plans going on, and our overages have been declining. So, all of those combinations are keeping it kind of stable.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Dave, nice try even though I said I wasnt going to comment further on the matter. But suffice to say that we are obviously actively involved in discussions with Clearwire, but we do have alternatives that we would consider. But, Id certainly dont
componenttext: Dave, nice try even though I said I wasnt going to comment further on the matter. But suffice to say that we are obviously actively involved in discussions with Clearwire, but we do have alternatives that we would consider. But, Id certainly dont want to suggest that that is our primary focus, but we always work to have alternatives.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sorry, had to try. But, Bob, could I just follow-up real quick Bob on that ARPU. I guess are you saying that these forces are kind of in tension and that irrespective of the smartphone upgrades and iDEN kind of going away, right now a flattish ARPU is rea
componenttext: Sorry, had to try. But, Bob, could I just follow-up real quick Bob on that ARPU. I guess are you saying that these forces are kind of in tension and that irrespective of the smartphone upgrades and iDEN kind of going away, right now a flattish ARPU is really the picture we should expect.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: So far what youre seeing is, if you will, the higher monthly recurring charges, more or less offset by, if you will, the loss of the overages and theyve been more or less canceling each other out. Over time, with momentum we have in smartphones and
componenttext:
So far what youre seeing is, if you will, the higher monthly recurring charges, more or less offset by, if you will, the loss of the overages and theyve been more or less canceling each other out. Over time, with momentum we have in smartphones and the $10 premium that were charging for certain heavy use smartphones, I think over time, you could expect that ARPU will begin to tick-up. But so far, if you will, typically people that price down do it more quickly.
So, so far youve had more or less of a cancellation. If you will, the two cancel each other out. You have higher MRCs, multi-recurring charges on average, fewer fees and overages. Of course, thats reflected on the positive side in churn, in churn improvements because customers dont like overages. If you just extrapolate those trends over time, you should expect to begin to see ARPU move up. I am not going to tell you when yet, but you should expect to see those begin to tick up going forward.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010

componenttext: Thanks a lot. Appreciate, Dan.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010

componenttext: Thank you, Dave.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010

componenttext: Your next question will come from Jason Armstrong.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, thanks, good morning. A couple of questions, both related to good the gross addition trajectory and thats sort of continuing to move up into next quarter. I guess, the first is with normal seasonality which would suggest a downtick in churn, it sho
componenttext:
Hi, thanks, good morning. A couple of questions, both related to good the gross addition trajectory and thats sort of continuing to move up into next quarter. I guess, the first is with normal seasonality which would suggest a downtick in churn, it should mean positive net adds or within reach in 4Q. Wondering how you would think through how likely that is.
And then second, as it relates to your gross adds continuing to move up and then a continued large device upgrade percentage in your base. It seems like no real relief on the horizon at least in the near term for wireless margins. So how should we think through your balancing efforts on postpaid and sort of improving the trajectory there relative to whats happening on the margin line.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, weve provided all the guidance that were going to provide with respect to Q4, and youll see if you will in our new guidance language or forecast language for Q4 that you could expect an improvement in both postpaid, prepaid and total net ad
componenttext:
Well, weve provided all the guidance that were going to provide with respect to Q4, and youll see if you will in our new guidance language or forecast language for Q4 that you could expect an improvement in both postpaid, prepaid and total net add performance sequentially in Q4 versus Q3, but I want to elaborate more than that, but clearly were working to improve those numbers.
With respect to upgrades, and I think youre getting at subsidies and what have you, that is kind of a challenge in our industry, where smartphones and this is related to the question give us benefits in ARPU and churn, but of course also have increased subsidy, so increased CPGA and then kind of increased cost of service that go with them.
And so far the benefits have outstripped the downside. We are working very closely and hard with our suppliers to continue to give us better priced phones and we work very hard on the mix, and thats why actually our cost for the devices was better this quarter than it was in previous quarters mainly because weve been able to work very effectively on not only device pricing, but device mix.
That being said, in terms of margins, if you look at the margins in our business, the biggest issue for us from a margin point of view is the cost of service associated with running two networks and it will take us, near the end of my comments on the earnings call, we have a network modernization plan out there that were currently evaluating.
Were going to decide and we havent yet who were choosing, what the economics are, how quickly we deploy that or what have you, but it takes a while to implement that so you wouldnt start to see the significant benefits of that probably occurring till 2012 or so. So thats the biggest opportunity we have, if you will, on the margin side is our activity on the network.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thank you.
componenttext: Great, thank you.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks for taking the question. I just want to follow-up on those last comments about network modernization. Youve talked about a lot of different objectives here, improved performance of the CDMA network, and some cost reductions over time. I was
componenttext: Yes, thanks for taking the question. I just want to follow-up on those last comments about network modernization. Youve talked about a lot of different objectives here, improved performance of the CDMA network, and some cost reductions over time. I was hoping I know youre not ready to give all the details yet, but you can maybe just sort of give us the order of magnitude, what bigger priorities are, is it more of a network performance project, is it more of a cost management project, and then how does iDEN fit into all that?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Bob Azzi. Im the Head of Network here. Just a comment on that. I would characterize, this really comes together the modernization of the network will help us to both reduce our costs and give us a technology flexibility, so it does come togethe
componenttext: This is Bob Azzi. Im the Head of Network here. Just a comment on that. I would characterize, this really comes together the modernization of the network will help us to both reduce our costs and give us a technology flexibility, so it does come together in the technology platform that were looking at.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: As Ive said earlier, our network performance is really very, very strong. So we actually see our networks currently as a competitive advantage, not a disadvantage, but then the alternative on the cost side, because were running two networks instead
componenttext:
As Ive said earlier, our network performance is really very, very strong. So we actually see our networks currently as a competitive advantage, not a disadvantage, but then the alternative on the cost side, because were running two networks instead of one network, we see our costs of running our network is a disadvantage.
So, in terms of overall priorities in terms of us doing this, the primary driver is cost reduction, and is economic improvement, but it has added benefits, if you will, the icing on the cake in terms of also giving us superior network performance, it makes it easier for us to more effectively use multimode technology. For example, and I mentioned, using the 800 MHz band for CDMA as well, and do that cost effectively. So the biggest driver is to improve our cost position. And it has added performance benefits that come along with it, because of the way technology has improved over the past few years.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And so you said that the big cost disadvantage is because you have two networks, does that mean that whenever this project ends which could go on for a few years, youd consolidate it down to one platform?
componenttext: And so you said that the big cost disadvantage is because you have two networks, does that mean that whenever this project ends which could go on for a few years, youd consolidate it down to one platform?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thats correct. Thats the plan, one overall platform. It doesnt mean one air interface, okay. I mean, I want to make sure one spectrum band, youll have multiple spectrum bands, but in essence it would give us the opportunity deploy, if you will
componenttext: Thats correct. Thats the plan, one overall platform. It doesnt mean one air interface, okay. I mean, I want to make sure one spectrum band, youll have multiple spectrum bands, but in essence it would give us the opportunity deploy, if you will, multiple air interfaces and if you will frequency bands on the same cell site and share common backhaul, share the same towers and what have you, which gives us a lot of economic benefit. So, you should think of if it is one, the way we think about it is, yes, we would go from multiple networks to one network.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010

componenttext: Great, thanks for taking the question.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, guys. Good morning. Good job. On the quarter, two questions if you dont mind. One on, Dan, can you maybe talk a little bit about LTE and when do you think your competitors are going to have decent coverage and decent handsets. Secondly and some
componenttext: Thanks, guys. Good morning. Good job. On the quarter, two questions if you dont mind. One on, Dan, can you maybe talk a little bit about LTE and when do you think your competitors are going to have decent coverage and decent handsets. Secondly and somewhat related to that, are you kind of against the fore, just maybe your thoughts on maybe doing joint 4G builds? I know, you talked about the network being the biggest part of your cost, but if someone like a Leap or PCS or T-Mobile or others wanted to do 4G build with you, would you be kind of for or against that?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, youll have to ask our competitors about their progress with respect to coverage and handsets, but I think coverage will come ahead of handsets, particularly with respect to Verizon. I think theyve said that. So, were going to try to maximiz
componenttext:
Well, youll have to ask our competitors about their progress with respect to coverage and handsets, but I think coverage will come ahead of handsets, particularly with respect to Verizon. I think theyve said that. So, were going to try to maximize our time to market advantage and youre right to ask the question about both, because you could have the same number of POPs, but if you dont have the device portfolio it doesnt do you that much good. So, our real strength is the fact that we have a more mature ecosystem in terms of devices and handsets.
As I mentioned earlier on the call, the EVO and Epic are out there and theyre getting tremendous reviews, both for 3G and 4G, so that is a strength. Secondly, we are always open to looking at anything that provides a good positive return for our shareholders, so we are not averse to looking at any joint initiatives that would make economic sense. It doesnt say we will do them, wont say we wont do them, but we would evaluate any opportunity that came forward.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the EVO, Epic, you clearly have a great advantage there, do you think this could last for 12 months, 2 years, your best guess on that time frame?
componenttext: Just on the EVO, Epic, you clearly have a great advantage there, do you think this could last for 12 months, 2 years, your best guess on that time frame?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wish. Its hard to say. Our expectation is that Verizon will get some decent handsets out there in 2011 to compete with us in 4G. But, again, well be in our second generation of handsets in 2011. Well continue to improve and expand our 4G handse
componenttext: I wish. Its hard to say. Our expectation is that Verizon will get some decent handsets out there in 2011 to compete with us in 4G. But, again, well be in our second generation of handsets in 2011. Well continue to improve and expand our 4G handset portfolio in 2011. So I think for a while we will have an advantage in terms of the selection of 4G handsets. I wont say how long, but Verizon is a very capable competitor, and they are investing heavily in this area. So we know they will be on our heels pretty quickly.

componenttext:
Okay. Thanks very much. Good morning. Bob, in terms of fourth quarter, one of the things that you reiterated was Clearwires intention to turn-on up to 120 million POPs. How does that affect your network expense in terms of payments for people like in New York City who have an EVO and are currently operating primarily in 3Q but will start using the 4G network? Is that going to be material delta sequentially? Any color you could give us there.
Also, in the release you noted that Clearwire is also not yet finalized, is sort of anything more you can tell us behind that, anything we should be looking out for there? And then finally, Dan, if you have any updated thoughts on tiered data pricing, that will be great?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, three questions there. One is that, do you expect in Q4 as we turn up these additional 4G markets to see kind of a material change associated with, I will call it, more 4G usage versus 3G usage, and the answer there would be no. Clearly, there are s
componenttext: Okay, three questions there. One is that, do you expect in Q4 as we turn up these additional 4G markets to see kind of a material change associated with, I will call it, more 4G usage versus 3G usage, and the answer there would be no. Clearly, there are some payments that go to Clearwire with respect to 4G usage of these devices, so there is some, but what we would call materiality, I would say no. You asked two more questions. One was, I think you wanted me to try to preannounce Clearwires earnings results. Was that...?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010

componenttext: Well, you had a discussion in the release that you didnt have last quarter. I just want to understand what was driving that, has anything changed versus last quarter or is that sort of -?

componenttext: Simon, Ill take that question. So, every quarter, we review our Safe Harbor statements and make updates and changes if necessary. Although the timing and procedures relating to the receipt of Clearwires financial information remains the same as previous periods, we added the language on the Clearwire results this quarter because Clearwire has become a more material part of our business.

componenttext: It was tiered data pricing, Dan. Thanks

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Tiered data pricing, yes, we continue to evaluate it, and the key will be looking at usage characteristics. Ive been asked this question before. There clearly is an advantage to having, if you will, unlimited or kind of headache-free simple pricing. Cu
componenttext:
Tiered data pricing, yes, we continue to evaluate it, and the key will be looking at usage characteristics. Ive been asked this question before. There clearly is an advantage to having, if you will, unlimited or kind of headache-free simple pricing. Customers like it and they will pay a premium for it. But we dont want to lose segments of the market because we dont have price points in other parts of the, if you will, the continuum of data use.
So, its something that we just continue to monitor. It helped us to not only improve churn, but lower our costs and improve the overall care and retail experience two years ago we eliminated 85% of our rate plan combinations, and that simplicity really helps the business. So, there are a lot of advantages to having a simple rate plan structure. But again, there is a lot of increased data usage and we want to make sure that were competitive and effective out there in the marketplace, so I will not rule out tiered data pricing.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thank you.
componenttext: Great, thank you.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Two quick questions if I may. Im wondering if you could remind us of the details of your 800 MHz spectrum position and where you are in the rebanding process. I cant remember if that affects the 800 MHz or not, and then getting into the deta
componenttext: Thanks. Two quick questions if I may. Im wondering if you could remind us of the details of your 800 MHz spectrum position and where you are in the rebanding process. I cant remember if that affects the 800 MHz or not, and then getting into the detail of repurposing that spectrum. How much do you need to reserve for the number of subscribers that you have left on the iDEN network, and how much does that free up for use on CDMA, and is the repurposing of that spectrum something you can do relatively soon before you go to the whole network transformation process, or does it have to wait for the network transformation process before you can start reusing it?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think Jonathan, the first part of the question had to do with was rebanding and the economics there; well, we had a letter of credit reduction in the third quarter, actually two of them that were a total of $255 million. So our letter of credit is now a
componenttext:
I think Jonathan, the first part of the question had to do with was rebanding and the economics there; well, we had a letter of credit reduction in the third quarter, actually two of them that were a total of $255 million. So our letter of credit is now at $1.33 billion, which is down from the original $2.5 billion, and weve incurred about $2.7 billion of costs so far. So, there is an outstanding letter of credit out there at $1.33 billion, but thats down $255 million this quarter and the rebanding process is likely to continue even beyond 2012, so the process will take some time.
With respect to your second question, yes, the network monetization project is a very, very important part of utilizing the 800 frequency for CDMA. It make sense to do that as part of the project and the other thing that goes along with it is new CDMA handsets that are also capable of operating at those lower 800 MHz frequencies that our existing base of handsets or not, its not a big change, its a fairly minor one, but its still something that we need to seed new devices into the marketplace. So, if you will, its not something that we will do immediately, so there are two elements in essence that were really waiting for before we do it in a, what we call, a meaningful fashion. I think you had one last question, Im not sure. There was one more question?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just how much total 800 MHz spectrum you have and whether thats affected by the rebanding process?
componenttext: Yes. Just how much total 800 MHz spectrum you have and whether thats affected by the rebanding process?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Basically after rebanding is complete well have 14 MHz across the markets. Ill also mention that in a number of the markets we do also have some holdings in 900 MHz that we also use for the iDEN customer base.
componenttext: Basically after rebanding is complete well have 14 MHz across the markets. Ill also mention that in a number of the markets we do also have some holdings in 900 MHz that we also use for the iDEN customer base.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: So are you able to do 2 paired 3.5 MHz channels, one pair for CDMA, and one pair for iDEN in that 14 MHz, is that how it will ultimately work?
componenttext: So are you able to do 2 paired 3.5 MHz channels, one pair for CDMA, and one pair for iDEN in that 14 MHz, is that how it will ultimately work?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010

componenttext: What our early part of the plan in markets where we have completed the rebanding process, we think we can get one CDMA carrier deployed for voice, which is what were looking at to help with the performance improvement, and as Dan mentioned, the handset chipsets have to come along with that to enable that.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Its putting in that CDMA carrier that enables you to reduce the 20,000 cell sites that you are hoping to take out over time?
componenttext: Its putting in that CDMA carrier that enables you to reduce the 20,000 cell sites that you are hoping to take out over time?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I dont think you can draw that extension correctly. I just want to emphasize were focused on the first steps of the plan right now, and then in the future, well evaluate how we rationalize that across the entire network.
componenttext: I dont think you can draw that extension correctly. I just want to emphasize were focused on the first steps of the plan right now, and then in the future, well evaluate how we rationalize that across the entire network.

componenttext: Yes, actually piggyback on some of those questions, obviously a lot of interest in the network modernization. You mentioned the $4.7 billion in cash, the debt maturities coming up, as you think about the network modernization plan, could be $2 billion, could be $3 billion if you think of how many base stations youre going to touch, how many years might that play out that capital spending? Given your cash balance, the debt maturities, and Dan I think you said, 2012 before you see some meaningful improvement in margins. Are we thinking about a two year plan, a five year plan?

componenttext: Id say three to four kind of in that range. It could potentially be longer. Well evaluate based upon our cash generation and cash needs. We still havent gotten to that point yet how quickly we will do this and implement it. So we have a choice of doing it more quickly or taking more time, and thats something that well evaluate later. So we have not reached a conclusion in that regard just like we havent picked the vendors, but think of four years as a rough ballpark.

componenttext: Yes. Some people were I think suggesting that maybe there was an immediate need of cash that might have to be all spent next year and it seems like the balance sheet could handle multiyear project pretty easily.

componenttext: Ric, its Bob. Yes. I think it can. In the last three years weve been generating close to $2 billion a year in cash, and 2012 is a peak, in the 2750 in 2012 is a highlight and then the debt retirements go down a little bit, so we should be able to managing this thing with good cash flow.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks and good morning. Dan, congrats on the good positive operating momentum. Im clearly looking forward to details on the margin expansion from the network monetization of making that 900, look a lot more like the 700 the Verizon and AT&T types are
componenttext:
Thanks and good morning. Dan, congrats on the good positive operating momentum. Im clearly looking forward to details on the margin expansion from the network monetization of making that 900, look a lot more like the 700 the Verizon and AT&T types are much full, but just a few quick questions here. Number one, on CapEx and the outlook there, were seeing a very high level of 3G network usage from these 4G customers where youre seeing good momentum. Can you talk about the extent to which you can focus on better network density in 2011, would be the first question?
And then just on the network monetization again, you pointed to 2012 in getting some benefits there. Should I be thinking about three to four years as the fastest timeframe you think itd be possible to rebuild the 38,000 strong CDMA network to take advantage of the new technology, and then just quick follow-up on the prepaid.

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: David, let me see if I can answer your questions. I think there is definitely going to be increasing tonnage if you will on both 3G as well as if you will for the previous question, usage of 4G going forward. So, as weve been doing this year, weve b
componenttext: David, let me see if I can answer your questions. I think there is definitely going to be increasing tonnage if you will on both 3G as well as if you will for the previous question, usage of 4G going forward. So, as weve been doing this year, weve been spending our capital to improve the capacity in coverage and service with respect to 3G, and you should expect to see that. You had a question though with respect to network density, and Im not sure what you meant by that?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the 4G side, Dan. I guess, Ive been a bit surprise by some customer feedback that the 3G usage has actually been a lot higher relative to 4G, and that could just be the Clearwire is just early out of the gate here and the network density is not that
componenttext: On the 4G side, Dan. I guess, Ive been a bit surprise by some customer feedback that the 3G usage has actually been a lot higher relative to 4G, and that could just be the Clearwire is just early out of the gate here and the network density is not that great in the areas that they have launched in. So, I was just curious as to whether youll have a bias on coverage versus improved network density in 2011. That seems to be just a key driver of the value proposition for Sprint?

headline: Sprint Nextel Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is something that we continue to discuss with Clearwire. The beauty of dual-mode devices are that, as you mentioned, you get 4G where 4G is there and you can fall back to pretty darn good 3G service where 3G is available. So, 3G usage on the mul
componenttext:
Yes, this is something that we continue to discuss with Clearwire. The beauty of dual-mode devices are that, as you mentioned, you get 4G where 4G is there and you can fall back to pretty darn good 3G service where 3G is available. So, 3G usage on the multimode devices is still fairly high, and you have to pick the time when you launch a market, and then as you well know, over time, our customer should expect that local coverage will improve very much like the earlier days at PCS when service roamed on analog in addition to digital, its no different.
So, over time, you will begin to see those coverage holes fill in, and if you will, 3G provides a very good safety net. In the early days of rolling this out, youre going to see fairly robust 3G usage. You also had a question about, is three to four years the fastest. Well, no, not necessarily, you mean the fastest that it could be done technically, but we look at a lot of factors, operating risk, financial, cash, and all those things that I just think four is probably a good midpoint if you will to think about in terms of how long we would take to roll this out.
